job_title: Health Systems, Policy and the Profession
application_procedure: This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies and Postdoctoral Fellows. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Visit the Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing website for instructions on how to apply for Teaching Assistant positions https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/current-students/teaching-assistantships/. The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position. The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodation at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at UofT, please visit our Accommodation webpage. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.

job_title: Principles of Genetic Analysis I Laboratory
application_procedure: Please submit a CI Cover Page (available on the departmental web site: (https://moleculargenetics.utoronto.ca/teaching-assistantships-ta) and a CV to Ab Atre (studentservices.mogen@utoronto.ca)
duties:
This is a laboratory course designed to introduce third- and fourth-year undergraduates to the principles and practice of genetic analysis in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic model organisms.  Student teams carry out genetic crosses, mutant hunts, and phenotypic/genotypic characterization in bacteria, phage, and yeast mutants, and learn to analyze, interpret, and present the genetic data obtained.  Students learn fundamental lab skills through experimentation (dilution streaking, cell culturing/counting, sterile technique, pipetting, serial dilutions, crossing strains etc. ) as well as standard genetic approaches including generating mutants, deducing gene function from phenotypic analysis, identifying genetic suppressors, characterizing mutant alleles (both phenotypically and genotypically),  ordering genes in a genetic pathway (epistasis analysis) and generating genetic interaction profiles.  Topics taught encompass the fundamental concepts of genetics: mutation, complementation, recombination, genetic suppression and regulation (epistasis)—and notably, how to apply the tools of genetic analysis, interpret the results and present the data.  While strong emphasis is placed on the “doing of proper genetics”—experimental design, the importance of controls, good lab habits (sterile technique, dilutions, organization and safe handling of all materials) are core learning objectives, as is the effective communication of scientific data through the production of high quality of data figures/tables and clear scientific writing. The model organisms used are Escherichia coli and Saccharomyces cerevisiae, both biosafety level 1 organisms.  

The MGY314H1F course is team taught in the fall semester (September to December) and consists of 12 weeks of genetics labs, broken up into two distinct parts (prokaryotic vs eukaryotic genetics).  Each section of the course is independently overseen by a separate instructor and run in conjunction with the Department of Teaching Labs who are responsible for the materials required for the wet lab sessions (including the biological and chemical reagents) and provide additional behind the scenes support such as growing cultures, extra replica platings, incubating plates and removing to cold, monitoring experiments for contamination etc. The instructor meets weekly (~1H) with the teaching assistants and DTL prior to each in-lab session (usually Monday or Tuesday) at a mutually convenient time to review the learning objectives for the lab, provide TA training, assess the results from the previous week's experiments and answer any questions about the week's lab (may also be done by email).   The sessional position is predominantly for the first 6 weeks of the course (focusing on bacterial genetics) and culminates in a 1H midterm test that is written and marked by the instructor.  In addition, the instructor contributes questions/marking of the final exam in December, which normally counts for ~20% of the final exam.  
	The overall format of the course is that each week, the instructor posts a 30 to 60 min background lecture on-line (on Mondays) that the students must view prior to attending the wet lab session each Thursday from 1-5 pm.  Student preparedness for the lab is assessed through existing on-line quizzes due before the wet lab starts.  As the background lecture counts as part of the 4H weekly lab course time allotment, most students will complete the in-lab portion of the course within 3H, however some lab sessions will go a bit longer.  The instructor is expected to attend all lab sessions, answer student questions, help prepare the lab beforehand, interface with DTL as well as contribute to the hiring, training, and supervision of the teaching assistants (who will be all new for 2024).  The approximate time commitment is 10 hours per week. Some interactions with students may be required to be done online.

The course has been taught for several years.  The successful applicant will have the support of the co-instructor/course coordinator who teaches the yeast section for the last 6 weeks of the course, manages the Quercus course page and takes the lead on hiring/training TAs and dealing with course administrative issues.  As all of the TAs for MGY314 will be new for 2024, the instructor will be involved in recruiting, training and supporting the TAs in carrying out the bacterial genetics experiments.   A laboratory manual, course slides, pre-recorded lectures, lab report templates (and marking notes), examples of prior assessments and other critical components are available and have already been used successfully.  Reagents and equipment for each lab are overseen by the Dept of Teaching labs who may have questions about the materials and occasionally require help troubleshooting experimental issues.  Minimal modification of course materials may be required to update them for use this year or in response to specific student challenges (for instance, we’ve had to reteach M1V1 to the covid cohorts as well as provide additional support in helping students learn to use basic graphing/table making software for their reports).
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications: Applicants will be considered on the basis of their practical familiarity with genetic analysis in model organisms as gained through some combination of coursework and research project work. Applicants should list in their curricula vitae the genetics courses they have completed, and for courses not offered at the University of Toronto, provide a brief summary of their content. Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department office and in the CUPE, Local 3902 office.
qualifications_minimum: The applicant must hold a completed or nearly completed PhD in the area of Microbiology or Molecular Genetics or other relevant field and is expected to obtain a valid biosafety certification for in-lab teaching (level 1 or higher).  They should be experienced with the concepts and methods of genetic analysis in E. coli, phage and budding yeast and have taken upper year undergraduate/graduate courses in the subject area, or alternatively have thesis and/or teaching experience in classical genetic analysis/microbiology.  The applicant should have demonstrated expertise in fundamental microbiological (E. coli) lab techniques and experimental genetic analysis techniques.  Previous teaching experience in classical genetics is desirable but not required. Awareness of the GSA Genetics Learning Framework (https://genetics-gsa.org/education/genetics-learning-framework/) and demonstrated pedagogical expertise in implementing the framework in an upper year undergraduate setting is an asset.

duties:
An asynchronous, online introductory survey course that explores the agents of infectious disease including bacteria, viruses, and parasites as well as the host immune response. Other topics include the fundamentals of disease diagnosis and epidemiology. This course will use web-based delivery of lectures and tutorials and utilize a range of communication tools equivalent to approximately three lectures per week.

Description of duties:
•	Regularly engage with students via Discussion Boards and email
•	Set due dates to course assignments, quizzes and projects 
•	Administer and mark course assignments, with support from TA’s
•	Create some lecture material, as necessary
•	Create short weekly introductory announcements via video or written post

job_title: English Composition and Introduction to Academic Writing
application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references to typ.office@utoronto.ca by Aug 20, 2024  at 10 AM.
duties: The Teaching Assistant (TA)  will support the course instructor in the instruction and management of TYP006 (English Composition) and WRR103 (Writing Essays). Both are core English courses at Transitional Year Programme at University of Toronto. These courses aim to improve students' confidence and abilities in expressing themselves and have the objective of equipping them to write university-level assignments. The courses also aim to improve students’ reading and analytic skills. The TA will support the course instructor in the general instruction and management of the courses. Duties range from grading and providing academic support for course assignments to holding consultation (office) hours and facilitating tutorials/ study groups; and from invigilating tests and exams to managing a variety of course-related clerical duties (e.g. updating content on Quercus). Additional duties will be determined in consultation with the course instructor and registrar. The TA may be required to attend seminars and lectures (asynchronous option available) and attend meetings. The courses are delivered in person with the possibility for online elements to be hosted on the University learning platform (Quercus). TAs must be available for in-person instruction and support. For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.

The candidate must demonstrate a commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education and familiarity with Quercus and online instructional methods.
qualifications_preferred:
The candidate must have: (a) Previous work experience and/ or coursework relating to educational access, anti-oppression, and social-justice approaches to post-secondary education.                                      (b) In-depth knowledge of the University of Toronto community and student experience.                                         (c) Knowledge of/ or experience with adult education and the University of Toronto Transitional Year Programme or similar programming. (d) Experience advising students and providing writing support in the social sciences and/ or humanities.  
Shortlisted candidates may be asked to complete a brief written screening question and/or an interview.

job_title: Pathways to Sustainability: An Interdisciplinary Approach - Lead Administrative TA
application_procedure:
For most recent course syllabus, go to: https://www.environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     

Applicants are required to apply to the Arts & Science TAship application website at: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/env/login       
Applications should include: i) a letter of application, explaining why you are qualified for the course(s) to which you are applying, and ii) a CV (including academic and applied environmental experience). Please note: The letter of application should be combined with your CV, and uploaded as a single file, where you are asked to upload your CV. 
Applicants are requested not to apply to TA positions for which they do not have the qualifications listed under "Qualifications".
duties: Duties include delivering 3 tutorials per week, for  10 weeks, coordinating the work of the other TA's, grading assignments, tests and final exams, holding office hours, providing administrative support, and general assistance. Additional duties supported through the Writing Integrated Teaching program, which may include additional training, benchmarking sessions, and other activities, for a total of 6 hours.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate students who have completed at least one year of graduate school, and have demonstrated scholarly expertise in Sustainability, that includes the topics listed in the course description. Course Description: ENV222H1 explores the concept and practice of sustainability by integrating scientific, technological, economic, political, psychological, historical, and ethical perspectives. The course begins by analyzing the challenges posed by the ecological crisis, including its historical roots. It then goes on to explore and evaluate a variety of approaches, strategies, and actions—at a personal, local, national, and global scale—that could move us towards authentic sustainability.
qualifications_preferred: An interdisciplinary environmental background is an asset.

job_title: Laboratory and Field Methods in Environmental Science
application_procedure:
For most recent course syllabus, go to: https://www.environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     

Applicants are required to apply to the Arts & Science TAship application website at: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/env/login       
Applications should include: i) a letter of application, explaining why you are qualified for the course(s) to which you are applying, and ii) a CV (including academic and applied environmental experience). Please note: The letter of application should be combined with your CV, and uploaded as a single file, where you are asked to upload your CV. 
Applicants are requested not to apply to TA positions for which they do not have the qualifications listed under "Qualifications".
duties: Duties include assisting with 10 class sessions in the lab or field, , grading lab and research reports, holding office hours, and general assistance. (*field trips will only occur if conditions permit)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate student in Biology or Ecology who has completed at least one or more years of graduate study and who has demonstrated scholarly expertise in environmental biology, including field work and sample collection.   Course Description: This course focuses on methods of sampling and analyzing natural air, water and solid Earth materials for physical, chemical and biological properties that are relevant to current environmental issues. It will integrate approaches from chemistry, physics, earth sciences and biology, and cover techniques in field sampling, laboratory analyses and analyses of large environmental data sets. Basic concepts related to quality control will be emphasized throughout the course: sample collection and storage methods, calibration of field and lab instruments, analyses in complex matrices, errors (accuracy, precision), and detection limits.
qualifications_preferred: Experience with the R programming language is an important asset.

job_title: Special Topics in Environment: Campus Community Food Systems Praxis
application_procedure:
For most recent course syllabus, go to: https://www.environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     

Applicants are required to apply to the Arts & Science TAship application website at: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/env/login       
Applications should include: i) a letter of application, explaining why you are qualified for the course(s) to which you are applying, and ii) a CV (including academic and applied environmental experience). Please note: The letter of application should be combined with your CV, and uploaded as a single file, where you are asked to upload your CV. 
Applicants are requested not to apply to TA positions for which they do not have the qualifications listed under "Qualifications".
duties: Duties include preparing and leading practicals during 12 weeks over fall and winter terms, grading assignments, tests, and final exams, holding office hours, and general assistance
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate student, who has a demonstrated scholarly expertise in environmental studies, particularly with respect to food and food security. Course Description: The industrial food system is a key propellant of the unprecedented, interconnected socio-ecological crises we face today. Yet a rich diversity of food systems alternatives – from sustainable and regenerative through to community-based and de-commodified – demonstrate the power of food systems to contribute to more socio-ecologically just worlds. In this class, we’ll aim to build on and contribute to these efforts through critical food systems praxis – or, the process of learning, action, and reflection. Students will have the opportunity to engage in an applied food systems research project with a campus or community partner while also gaining hands-on experience in food growing, preserving, and preparing. The projects available will range across the social and biophysical sciences; for example, experiments with agroecology and regenerative food systems, or engagement with food sovereignty movements and local food policies. Students will also have opportunities to reflect on the role of experiential learning, interdisciplinary community-engaged research, and action in effecting positive social and ecological change.
qualifications_preferred: Experience (a) with research in critical food studies from interdisciplinary perspectives, (b) growing food, and (c) working with community partners and diverse social organizations an asset.
salery: $51.93/hour + 4% vacation pay fall 2024; $52.97/hour + 4% vacation pay for winter 2025

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

Academic background in Statistical Sciences, Computer Science, or related discipline.  PhD student (or graduate) in statistics, computer science, biostatistics, epidemiology or related disciplines.
Must have experience with: 
-	Python and Jupyter notebooks for programming and data analysis.  
-	Analysis of text data.
qualifications_preferred: Familiarity or interest in applying statistical methods or computational methods in the humanities, previous TA experience in courses that cover introductory statistics and computer programming topics are preferred.

department: Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy
application_procedure: All individuals interested in this position must submit an updated Curriculum Vitae and Cover Letter and TA evaluations to Professor Alexandra Rahr alexandra.rahr@utoronto.ca and cc the Undergrad Coordinator - Munk School of Global Affairs & Public undergraduatecoordinator.munkschool@utoronto.ca.
duties: The course runs from 2:00 – 4:00 PM on Wednesdays. The TA will be responsible for attending class, running one discussion-based tutorial (20-30 students) from 4:00 – 5:00 PM on Wednesdays or 12:00 – 1:00 PM on Thursdays. In addition to managing discussions, running the tutorial includes tracking attendance and participation, marking two short assignments, compiling peer feedback, and grading the final exam. Your supervisor, Darius Ornston, is available for weekly meetings to plan tutorial sessions (this is included in the hourly estimate). He can provide exercises and notes for each tutorial, but experimentation is encouraged and the TA is welcome to take a more active role in co-creating course content.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Must be currently enrolled in a Social Sciences or Humanities PhD program, or enrolled in the Centre for European and Eurasian Studies, Master of Global Affairs, or Master of Public Policy MA program (with teaching experience preferred), at the University of Toronto.
qualifications_preferred: Interdisciplinary experience (which could include a liberal arts background) is preferred. This is not an economics class, but some introductory coursework or familiarity with the subject would be an asset in the Public Policy and Peace Conflict and Justice modules.

a)a resource expert to support students doing the MFin online self-study review module which covers the introduction to derivative securities. Based on the posted background material (textbook chapters, slides, videos, and review questions), the T.A. may prepare some additional examples and videos to emphasize key points; and will also schedule some periodic opportunities throughout the term, and prior to the test in early January, for students to get assistance and ask questions (tutorials, Q&A sessions, etc.).
Spring (January 2025 – April 2025)  :
a)Assist in grading assignments; b) Assist during some classes to support students’ participation in simulation cases and to assist the instructor by co-piloting the market simulator server; c) hold tutorials and office hours, particularly to assist with coding questions; d) other duties as assigned.

qualifications_minimum:
A bachelors degree in commerce (finance specialization).  The ideal candidate will combine knowledge of financial derivatives (institutional features, pricing, and applications) from undergraduate or graduate course work with experience analyzing investment decisions and / or risk management related to portfolios with derivatives exposure. The candidate should have a practical understanding of strategy implementation risks in capital markets derived from work experience in trading or portfolio management.
One TA to cover both duties/terms preferred.

duties: The primary duty for this position involves preparing for and facilitating a series of 4 works-in-progress seminar style sessions with approximately 15 teacher candidates per section of the course the TA is supporting. Teacher candidates are expected to come prepared to works-in-progress sessions with an update on the status of their literature review research and their progress, and they will each have a turn to seek specific guidance from the group and the TA, and to ask questions and seek clarification on assignment guidelines. The TA is expected to dialogue with the TCs and provide specific and generative feedback on each TCs status report. The TA is also expected to initially meet with the course instructors for each section of the course they are supporting, and to communicate an overview summary of each session--informing the instructor of any student/s who may be struggling. The TA is also expected to familiarize themselves closely with the literature review assignment expectations and evaluation instruments so that they can provide accurate and supportive guidance. Duties may also include preparing and/or reviewing resources to support students in their literature reviews.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should possess experience writing literature reviews and have experience conducting qualitative research. They should have a demonstrated commitment to researcher reflexivity and critical citation practice. Candidates are expected to have experience teaching and/or supporting academic writing and experience with research design and qualitative research methods. Candidates should possess strong organizational and communication skills (oral and written), and have experience providing substantive and specific feedback on student work. Demonstrated knowledge and practice of equity, diversity and inclusion required.
qualifications_preferred: Experience with academic coaching would be considered a strong asset. An Ontario Teaching Certificate is an asset.

application_procedure:
Please visit https://ecp.engineering.utoronto.ca/job-opportunities/application-procedures-cupe-unit-1-positions/ for details on the application procedure.  

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Chanelle Small-reid at istep.academic@utoronto.ca .
duties:
Participate in ongoing course development. Attend biweekly course planning meetings. Attend one lecture each week (M 12–13) and help run biweekly 2-hour (alternating) workshops (W 12–14). Supervise work of approximately 30 students working in teams and individually. Hold consultations with students to help them develop as writers and presenters. 

Grade a variety of shorter and longer written assignments and presentations within agreed-upon turnaround times. Exact assessment schedule is under revision. Grading duties and timelines will be developed in cooperation with course TAs prior to the course start.

Please note that some duties may be adjusted depending on potential changes to the course description. Ability to convert to online duties if required.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto, or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto, in an appropriate discipline (such as, but not limited to, Communication, English, Engineering, Education, Technology Studies) with strong written and oral communication skills, a demonstrated commitment to teaching communication, and a demonstrated ability to work as a member of a team.
qualifications_preferred: Assets include a bachelor of applied science in materials science and engineering, familiarity with engineering communication practices and/or training in second-language instruction at the university level. Familiarity with SolidWorks is also an asset.
salery: $51.93 per hour + vacation pay (as of Jan 1, 2024). Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure:
To apply, please email your CV, teaching evaluations (if available), and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT235Y".

If you've already applied for any Fall 2024- Winter 2025 positions you don't need to include CV and evaluations again unless there are  any changes.
duties: The instructor will be a member of a coordinated team with a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator, the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.           Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2020, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

job_title: Creative Applications of Natural Language Processing
department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure:
Apply on the Electrical and Computer Engineering on-line TA Database. Instructions and link are posted on the ECE TA web page: https://www.ece.utoronto.ca/faculty/career-opportunities/ or directly at: https://eceta2.ece.toronto.edu/.  Incoming students who do not have a UTORid yet should be able to use their JOINid to log in.

 If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: Grading assignments, helping students with assignments, grading interim deliverables for the projects, mentoring student projects.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred:
Good understanding and experience in the core knowledge of Machine Learning and Neural networks, including classification, regression, binary/multiclass classification, supervised and unsupervised learning.  MLPs, CNNs, loss function design, gradient descent and back propagation, regularization.  Debugging neural networks. Hyper parameter tuning, training, validation and testing.  Transfer learning/fine tuning. Core data science concepts. Must be very literate in the PyTorch neural network software library, including acceleration on GPUs and TPUs.

Strong literacy and experience in Natural Language processing based on deep learning, including the Torchtext and Hugginface libraries.  Good understanding of word embeddings and their manipulation and comparison.  Experience in training and using Transformers, including BERT GPT 2, 3, 4, 4o and chatGPT.   Understanding and experience in Prompt engineering and new methods of improving prompts.  Good communication skills and teaching skills.  Experience in mentoring open-ended projects, and skilled in mentoring students using this material for such projects.

application_procedure: Submit, cover letter, resume, course list, and application form by email to test.exam@utoronto.ca. https://lsm.utoronto.ca/ats/forms/2024-2025%20Employment%20Application-Invigilator.pdf
duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing tests and examinations written by students with documented disabilities who are registered with Accessibility Services at the University of Toronto, St. George Campus.

Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following:
--Maintaining the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental, academic faculty, and university policies and procedures
--Maintaining confidentiality of student and test/exam information
--Ensuring the provision of accommodations to students as specified by Accessibility Services
--Monitoring test/exam time allotments
--Handling student concerns/problems and escalating to the Coordinator, Accommodated Testing Services, as needed.
--Documenting and responding to anomalous situations
--Preparing completed tests/exams for return delivery
--Maintaining required administrative records

Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled, therefore minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed. The test centre is open from 7:00 AM to 11:00 PM and applicants are required to provide availability between the hours of 7:00 AM and 11:00 PM, Monday to Friday with a minimum of 10 hours of availability each week. Applicants are expected to provide a high level of availability during final exam periods in December and April. Please outline your availability in your cover letter.
qualifications:
Successful applicants must be eligible for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work, must be registered with the School of Graduate studies, and are expected to maintain their eligibility through the duration of the appointment. Any status change must be communicated to the Department, to determine eligibility to continue in the appointment.

Applicants must be available for the following mandatory in-person training sessions: 
1. Tuesday, September 17, 1-5pm.
2. Wedneday, September 18, 1-5pm
3. Friday, September 20, 1-5pm.

This is an on-campus, in-person position. Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts.

Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion.

Skills (listed alphabetically):
--Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries
--Ability to remain calm under pressure 
--Communication (both oral and written)
--Initiative
--Interpersonal  
--Organizational
--Problem solving
--Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities
--Strong computer skills including MS Office (Word, Excel, and Teams) and Zoom
--Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures and legislation

Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply

experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates must be enrolled in a graduate degree program at the University of Toronto and have equivalent experience specific to the subject matter. department: OISE Department of Leadership, Higher, and Adult Education
application_procedure: To apply for this position, please send a cover letter, c.v., the names of three referees and a detailed course description including possible topics, structure of course material, and expected learning outcomes to lhae.ea@utoronto.ca by Aug 8, 2024.
duties: Prepare, organize, and lead this graduate half course; be available to students seeking assistance between classes; and evaluate student work and provide students with feedback.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates must hold a doctorate in Higher Education or a related field; have a demonstrated record of scholarship in the field of Higher Education and the subject area of the course; have practical experience related to the topic of the course; and have successful graduate teaching experience in the subject area of the course and a successful track record of teaching online, preferably using Canvas/Quercus.
qualifications_preferred: n/a
salery: Minimum stipend is $8,142.51 (per half course, excludes vacation pay)

department: Department of Applied Psychology and Human Development
application_procedure: All applications must be received by August 7, 2024. To be considered for this position, please include 1. One-page cover letter outlining what the applicant brings to the position; 2. Current Curriculum Vitae; 3. Course Evaluations of all recent courses taught, if applicable. If you are a current/former U of T Sessional and require assistance retrieving your course evaluations, please contact your department ahead of the application deadline; 4. Names of referees may also be included but are not required. Applications should be sent to aphdsessional.oise@utoronto.ca, APHD Chair, Department of Applied Psychology and Human Development, OISE 252 Bloor St. West, Toronto, ON M5S 1V6. If during the application and/or selection process, you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact aphdsessional.oise@utoronto.ca.
duties: Instructors are required to: 1. Teach a minimum of 36 hours; 2. Prepare teaching resources for each class and provide relevant materials; 3. Assess and evaluate students' work and provide a final grade according to OISE/UT grading practices; 4. Be available for informal meetings/communications with students as necessary.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: 1. Candidate must be working towards a doctoral degree in psychology or a related field; 2. Expertise in content area; 3. Experience conducting and/or knowledge of play research and implementation of play in educational settings.
qualifications_preferred: 1. Preference will be given to individuals with demonstrated expertise with related course content; 2. Prior experience teaching graduate courses prefered; 3. Demonstrated scholarship in the area of the course topic.
salery: Minimum stipend is $8,142.51 (per half course, excludes vacation pay) for a half (F/S) course.

department: Centre for the Study of the United States
application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter, C.V. (including previous teaching evaluations (if applicable)), and a list of references by August 12, 2024. Applications should be sent electronically to Professor Leah Montange at 20TUleah.montange@utoronto.caU20T with a CC to csus@utoronto.ca.
duties:
•	Marking/grading student papers and assignments
•	Calculation and submission of grades
•	Attend classes throughout the semester
•	Holding office hours for academic counselling of students (including electronic consultation)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Teaching experience in grading, preferably in American-focused courses, as well as an Americanist research focus are preferred. First consideration will be given to full-time graduate students at the University of Toronto.

application_procedure: Applications should be made, with current curriculum vitae, proposed course outline, teaching statement, evidence of teaching effectiveness and a list of references. Application materials should be submitted to the attention of Prof. Michelle Silver, Chair, Department of Health Studies, University of Toronto Scarborough, 1265 Military Trail, Toronto, Ontario M1C1A4. All applications must be submitted to the Online Teaching Application at: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/chs/app/instr.
duties: Please note that classes will be held in person. All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; supervising TAs, holding regular office hours.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants’ research area and qualifications should be closely related to course material. Demonstrated ability to design syllabus in accordance with department guidelines. Ability to coordinate multiple tutorials, lectures to large classes, explain a variety of methodologies to an undergraduate student body.  Evidence of progress in the Ph.D. program.

job_title: Advanced Topics in Health and Society

application_procedure: Fill out application form found here (https://moleculargenetics.utoronto.ca/teaching-assistantships-ta) and send CV to studentservices.mogen@utoronto.ca
duties: Current aspects of human and molecular genetics including: human genome/chromosome/gene structure and function, epigenetics, comparative genomics, rare and complex disease mechanisms, human disease modelling, population genetics, genome wide association studies, cancer genetics, genetic testing and the genome clinic, genetic disease treatment, and ethical questions in clinical genetics. This course is taught by expert faculty and assumes solid background knowledge in classical genetics, gene structure and function, biochemistry, and cell biology.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications: Applicants will be considered on the basis of their familiarity with bioinformatics practices in the molecular biology research lab using the R Programming language & must have completed undergraduate training in this area, or have gained equivalent experience through research project work.  Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department & the CUPE office.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants will be considered on the basis of their practical familiarity with human genetics, population genetics, and genomics. This would include population genetics in other species, cancer genetics, DNA repair, modeling human disease, mammalian-genome related bioinformatics, as gained through some combination of coursework & research project work. Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department & CUPE office.

duties:
“- Delivering the lectures in-person as scheduled.
- Maintaining course administration including: course website on quercus, marking schemes, lectures, tutorials, assignments, tests, and final assessments.
- Providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, email, the course website and/or the course bulletin board.
- Preparing the breakdown of hours for TA duties in the course and supervising the TAs.
- Ensuring that tutorials and/or labs are delivered appropriately by the TAs.
- Managing the grading for the course, which is largely done by the TAs, and carrying out any grading not handled by the TAs.
- Managing the grades and submitting final course grades, including the timely completion and release of grades and feedback to students throughout the term
- Invigilating the final exam if applicable. 
- As there are other sections of the same course that term, coordinating with the other instructor(s) to maintain consistency (this includes using common assignments and a common final exam); 
- where relevant, instructors must work together to coordinate automarking of assignments.

While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course, and must get approval from these faculty members or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate on any substantial changes to the course content or assessment methods. Instructors will also be expected to consult with the department's Teaching Support group when creating the course syllabus, final exam, and test(s).
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

- demonstrated expertise in topic area of the course

A description of courses is available at https://artsci.calendar.utoronto.ca/section/Religion#programs_view-block_2-5.

Applications should be addressed to Professor Srilata Raman. Please send your application as a single PDF file to religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca. Course evaluations should be sent as a separate PDF file. The subject line of the email should read Unit 1 Application: [course code].
duties: Presenting weekly lectures and classes as appropriate, grading papers and exams, meeting with students individually as they request, and handling the other pedagogical and administrative tasks ordinarily associated with an undergraduate course. Working with the Experiential Learning Office and community partners to determine placements for students.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD candidacy in the Department for the Study of Religion or a completed PhD in religion or a related field. Ability to addres the themes of the course to which the application is being made.
qualifications_preferred: Demonstrated teaching experience as a teaching assistant, teaching fellow, or course instructor; extensive knowledge of the subject area and/or previous experience in the course is highly desirable.

duties:
Attending a one-hour instructional team meeting per week 
Attending up to six lectures per term 
Supervising 14-16 student teams (3 students per team) as project manager (30-minute meeting times to take place both within and outside of tutorial hours, 8-9 meetings per team over the term) 
Commenting on weekly team progress reports  
Meeting with students for consultation on request 
Facilitating practice oral presentations for the second oral presentation, and as needed through the term 
Grading a short individual explanation of a hardware component, a longer team design proposal, a midterm team oral presentation and a final team oral presentation 
Must be available  for a minimum of two pre-scheduled 2-hour tutorial slots plus one evening session during the week of the first oral presentation 
Must have the ability to adapt to different communication instruction activities and move online if required.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: "This course is an introduction to engineering design processes, illustrated through the design and implementation of a hardware system. In addition to familiarizing students with hardware design practices, tools, and skill sets, it also aims to develop effective oral and written communication in a team context. Principles of hardware design, project management and teamwork are developed in the lectures and tutorials, and students apply these concepts in the laboratories as they work in a team to design and implement a complex hardware system. Students learn and practice oral and written communication techniques in lectures and in meetings with their communication instructor and apply these techniques in a variety of documents and presentations, such as short status reports and longer design proposals and design reviews. Minimum Qualifications: include at least a Master’s degree in an appropriate discipline (such as, but not limited to, Communication, English, Engineering, Education, Technology Studies) with strong writing and oral communication skills, and a demonstrated commitment to teaching communication and demonstrated ability to work as part of a team. Flexible availability is a requirement for these positions. "
qualifications_preferred: include a PhD in an appropriate discipline (as above), TESL or CESLA certificate (or equivalent in ESL specialization or development of ESL curricula), familiarity with engineering communication practices and/or experience as an instructor in first year foundation course, Engineering Strategies and Practice. Also considered assets are experience in curriculum development, tutoring and/or working with a diverse group of students.
salery: In accordance with the current CUPE 3902, Unit 1 collective agreement, the rate of pay applicable for course instructors will be $$9,276.01 (excludes vacation pay) per half course and $19,642.56 (excludes vacation pay) per full course.
tutorial: Students attend two one-hour lectures, one two-hour lab and one 30-minute meeting with a Communication Instructor.

application_procedure: Please apply by email, with a cover letter and curriculum vitae to angela.umbrello@utoronto.ca
duties:
Teaching a course titled “The Context of Mental Health & Health Practice” based on the approved course outline.  The instructor must adhere to course policies on teaching and holding the course at the scheduled time.  The course content, notes, readings, and assignments are uniform across all sections.  The teaching team meets regularly to discuss teaching and learning activities and instructors are expected to attend these meetings.  This course has a significant amount of grading with quick turnaround for a couple of assignments.  For all assignments and final grades, instructors are expected to meet established deadlines. It is important to have consistency across all sections and the course coordinator is available to support new instructors.    
Quercus management: including learning and utilizing Quercus; the marking and grading of student work and the submission of grades to the course coordinator by the required date; adhering to the policies on teaching and holding classes when scheduled; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside of scheduled contact hours.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

qualifications_preferred: PhD in progress in social work with a preference given to candidates who have an MSW and are a Registered Social Worker (membership with the Ontario College of Social Workers and Social Service Workers). duties:
Fall (September 2024 – December 2024) duties will be:
a)a resource expert to support students doing the MFin online self-study review module which covers the introduction to derivative securities. Based on the posted background material (textbook chapters, slides, videos, and review questions), the T.A. may prepare some additional examples and videos to emphasize key points; and will also schedule some periodic opportunities throughout the term, and prior to the test in early January, for students to get assistance and ask questions (tutorials, Q&A sessions, etc.).
Spring (January 2025 – April 2025) duties will be :
a)Assist in grading assignments; b) Assist during some classes to support students’ participation in simulation cases and to assist the instructor by co-piloting the market simulator server; c) hold tutorials and office hours, particularly to assist with coding questions; d) other duties as assigned.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
A bachelors degree in commerce (finance specialization).  The ideal candidate will combine knowledge of financial derivatives (institutional features, pricing, and applications) from undergraduate or graduate course work with experience analyzing investment decisions and / or risk management related to portfolios with derivatives exposure. The candidate should have a practical understanding of strategy implementation risks in capital markets derived from work experience in trading or portfolio management.
One TA to cover both duties/terms preferred.

application_procedure: submit cover letter, academic record to d.ballyk@utoronto.ca
duties: meetings with Course Director, preparation for lab demonstration, lab demonstration, holding in-lab review sessions prior to assessments, invigilation of assessments, marking of tests, uploading of grades
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful completion of an undergraduate course or courses in human gross anatomy, histology and neuroanatomy at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required
qualifications_preferred: Experience teaching human gross anatomy, histology, and neuroanatomy is an asset.

job_title: Introduction to Medicine, Concepts, Patients, and Communities - 1, Concepts, Patients, and Communities -2
application_procedure: Please submit CV and cover letter (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) to Dr. Danielle Bentley via email, danielle.bentley@utoronto.ca
duties:
Basic Training / Attendance at onboarding meeting with Course Instructor.
Leading in-person, hands-on, human anatomy laboratories that focus on the gross anatomy of the back, thorax, abdomen, pelvis. 
Demonstrating dissection of human cadavers. 
Demonstrating gross anatomy using models, bones, and human cadaveric prosections. 
Meeting with the Course Instructor prior to every in-person laboratory and in-person MAPS session. 
Participating in TA training sessions.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Successful completion of a practical course in human gross anatomy at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required. 

Experience in human cadaveric dissection is required.
qualifications_preferred:
Experience teaching practical human gross anatomy is an asset. 

An MD degree, completed or in progress, from the University of Toronto or equivalent is an asset.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, C.V. (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) no later than August 5th, 2024 to email: Tania Alexson, Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Teaching Stream (tania.alexson@utoronto.ca)
duties: Basic Training / Attendance at onboarding meeting with Course Instructor Leading in-person, hands-on, human anatomy laboratories that focus on the gross anatomy of the musculoskeletal system; a total of 3. Demonstrating gross anatomy using models, bones, and human cadaveric prosections. Meeting with the Course Director prior to every in-person laboratory.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful completion of a practical course in human gross anatomy at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required.
qualifications_preferred: Experience working with prosected human cadaveric materials in regards to the musculskeletal system is an asset. Experience as a teaching assistant for a course in human gross anatomy is also an asset. Furthermore, an MD degree, completed or in progress, from the University of Toronto or equivalent is an asset.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, C.V. (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) no later than August 5th, 2024 to email: Tania Alexson, Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Teaching Stream (tania.alexson@utoronto.ca)
duties: Basic Training / Attendance at onboarding meeting with Course Instructor Leading in-person, hands-on, human anatomy laboratories that focus on the gross anatomy of the nervous system; a total of 3 in-person labs. This will include one dissection, but the majority will be completed by demonstrating neuroanatomy using models and human cadaveric prosections. In addition, leading 4 online virtual laboratories with an emphasis on pathways and case studies. Meeting with the Course Director prior to every in-person laboratory.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful completion of a practical course in human gross anatomy with a strong neuroanatomy unit or a course dedicated to human neuroanatomy (eg. HMB 320S) at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required.
qualifications_preferred: Experience in human cadaveric dissection of the human brain is an asset. Experience teaching neuroanatomy is also asset. Furthermore, an MD degree, completed or in progress, from the University of Toronto or equivalent is an asset.

application_procedure: Please submit CV and cover letter (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) to Dr. Danielle Bentley via email, danielle.bentley@utoronto.ca
duties:
Attendance at Meeting with Course Instructor.
Preparation and Instruction of Review Sessions and Q&A Sessions. 
Marking of Course Assessments (i.e. in-class case studies, written term tests, final exam).
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Previous completion of a full-year Human Anatomy course is required.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience as a Human Anatomy TA is an asset.

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure:
Apply on the Electrical and Computer Engineering on-line TA Database. Instructions and link are posted on the ECE TA web page: https://www.ece.utoronto.ca/faculty/career-opportunities/ or directly at: https://eceta2.ece.toronto.edu/.  Incoming students who do not have a UTORid yet should be able to use their JOINid to log in.

 If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: Duties may include  running the laboratory experiments in the ECE Energy Systems Labs, and marking tutorial/laboratory work, problem sets, tests and examinations.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Knowledge and experience with power electronic converters. Knowledge and experience with EV sub-systems including motor drives, batteries and charging systems. Experience with high voltage systems and safety (ECE314 or equivalent).

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please submit a Unit 1 Course Instructor Application Form, Resume and Teaching Dossier to the MIE Undergraduate Office by email at ugservices@mie.utoronto.ca no later than August 8, 2024 at 11:59PM (Eastern Time). The Course Instructor Application Form can be found on the MIE Careers page here: https://www.mie.utoronto.ca/faculty-staff/careers/. Applicants must include full contact information of their supervisor, plus two U of T employees (faculty or staff) who can testify to the teaching skills of the applicant.  The appointment will be made at the earliest possible time before the commencement of classes by the Associate Chair (Undergraduate) of the Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering.  No other offers or notices of the outcome of applications are authorized by the Department.  Final availability of the position is contingent upon final course determination, enrolment, budgetary considerations, and the final determination of assignments flowing from Article 14:03 of the Collective Agreement.
duties: Preparation of lectures and course materials; delivery of lectures; supervision of Teaching Assistants; setting and marking of tests and exams; evaluation of final grades; contact with students.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants should have a strong record of presenting lectures or acting as a teaching assistant.  Applicants must be able to demonstrate considerable depth of knowledge and experience in the subject area.  All applicants should have excellent communication skills - both oral and written. Professional Engineer (P.Eng.) or Limited License (LEL) is strongly preferred. Engineering Intern (EIT) is also acceptable.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

application_procedure: 1. See Course Instructor job postings and application procedures information on the department website at https://www.economics.utoronto.ca/index.php/index/graduate/gciOpenings and https://unit1.hrandequity.utoronto.ca/. 2. If interested, please submit an application to the Joseph Steinberg, Teaching Coordinator (https://uoft.me/ecocourseinstructor). On your application, please specify which course instructor position(s) you are applying for in order of preference. Also submit in PDF format a copy of your resume along with a note (email is fine) from your thesis supervisor indicating s/he is satisfied with your program progress and supports your application.
duties: 1.  Preparation and delivery of lectures in the course. 2.  Supervision of T.A(s) assigned to course. 3.  Preparation, supervision and grading of tests and examinations in accordance with University regulations as described in the Faculty of Arts & Science Academic Handbook. 4.  Providing scheduled office hours for academic counseling of students. 5. All or majority of duties are planned to be in-person, but they may also have online component.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolment as full-time student in the Ph.D. program in Economics at the U of T
qualifications_preferred: Completion of all PhD course requirements including 2nd year paper preferred
salery: Rate of pay: Current rates as of January 1, 2024 - $9094.13 (per half course, excluding vacation pay). Course Instructors (first time CI’s) - effective January 1, 2024 - $10163.28 (per half course, excluding vacation pay).  Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure:
Applicants must submit a cover letter and resume, clearly indicating any previous invigilation experience. University of Toronto student number and confirmation of registration status on ACORN is required. Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above is required.  Applicants must also confirm availability to invigilate weekday evening and weekend examinations.  
Applications should be addressed to the Assistant Dean, Graduate Programs and must be submitted by email to gpllm@utoronto.ca.
Please note that incomplete applications will not be considered
duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing of tests and examinations by students enrolled in the Global Professional Master of Laws (GPLLM) program at the Faculty of Law.  Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: maintaining the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental and university policies and procedures, verifying student identification, maintaining the confidentiality of student and text/exam information, monitoring test/exam time allotments, handling student concerns/problems and escalating any issues to the Assistant Director, GPLLM and/or Assistant Dean, Graduate Programs, documenting and responding to anomalous situations, gathering completed tests/exams and returning them to the program team, scanning handwritten exams for distribution to instructors, maintaining required administrative records.

Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled.  As a result, minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed.  Most exams are written on evenings (e.g., 5:00 to 10:00 p.m.) and weekends (12:00 to 5:00 p.m.), and applicants are required to be able to accommodate invigilating exams that are held according to these schedules during both mid-term and final examination periods.  See note below re: need to confirm availability to invigilate weekday evening and weekend exams at the time of application.
qualifications:
This position is open to NEW applicants. Applicants who have previously invigilated exams in the GPLLM Program needn’t re-apply. Applicants must be currently registered as students pursuing a degree at the University of Toronto and must continue to be registered as students throughout the duration of the appointment (thereby maintaining their eligibility for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work).  Any status change must be communicated to the GPLLM program immediately, so that eligibility to continue in the appointment can be determined. This is an on-campus, in-person position. Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts.  Experience invigilating tests and exams is strongly preferred.  Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion. 

Skills (listed alphabetically): Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries, ability to demonstrate integrity and professionalism while remaining calm under pressure, communication (both oral and written), initiative, interpersonal, organizations, problem solving and resourcefulness, attention to detail, situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities, understanding and the ability to apply relevant university and government policies, procedures and legislation, ability to collaborate with others and work in a team setting.
Relevant Criterion: 
Students enrolled in the LLM, MSL or GPLLM programs at the Faculty of Law are ineligible to apply for these positions.  

Preference will be given to applicants in the Faculty of Law’s SJD program. Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
salery: $34.22 + $1/hour worked on Saturday and Sunday shifts + 4% vacation pay. Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

duties:
Teaching Assistants will work as Teamwork and Communication Instructors (TCIs) and be required to conduct tutorial workshops alongside a disciplinary TA, work with students (both individually and in teams) and grade assignments, as well as work with the coordinator and other TAs on curriculum development. This position may require TCI's to lead tutorials throughout the term; TCI's are always suppored by the other TA in the tutorial workshops. 

Duties include: Weekly Two-hour tutorials Winter term. weekly/bi-weekly meetings with MIE coordinator and other TAs to prepare tutorial materials and benchmark assignments. Grading written work and oral presentations. Ability to convert to online duties if required.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should have at least an undergraduate degree and currently be enrolled in a Masters or PhD program in engineering (Mechanical or Industrial preferred but not essential).
qualifications_preferred: Candidates must have strong written and oral communication skills, teamwork, leadership skills and a demonstrated commitment to teaching communication and teamwork. In addition, assets would include familiarity with engineering communication practices and/or training in second-language instruction at the university level.  This course is team-taught, the ability to work as part of a team is essential, both at the individual tutorial level and as part of a larger teaching team. Experience as a student or TA in the first year foundation course, Engineering Strategies and Practice or any other engineering communication courses, is desirable.
salery: $52.97 per hour + vacation pay (as of Jan 1, 2025). Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties:
“- Delivering the lectures in-person as scheduled.

- Providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, email, the course website and/or the course bulletin board.

- Ensuring that tutorials and/or labs are delivered appropriately by the TAs.
- Managing the grading for the course, which is largely done by the TAs, and carrying out any grading not handled by the TAs.
- Managing the grades and submitting final course grades, including the timely completion and release of grades and feedback to students throughout the term
- Invigilating the final exam if applicable. 
- As there are other sections of the same course that term, coordinating with the other instructor(s) to maintain consistency (this includes using common assignments and a common final exam); 
- where relevant, instructors must work together to coordinate automarking of assignments.

While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course, and must get approval from these faculty members or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate on any substantial changes to the course content or assessment methods. Instructors will also be expected to consult with the department's Teaching Support group when creating the course syllabus, final exam, and test(s).

- demonstrated expertise in topic area of the course

department: Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy
application_procedure: Please email Resume/CV, and teaching evaluations (if applicable) to munk.one@utoronto.ca
duties: Deliver a course in the Munk One program on Climate, Energy, and Power. This course explores the relationship between energy practices and social and economic power. This class considers the inequality caused by climate change, emergent energy technologies, and the institutional and regulatory conditions that shape national, regional, and international environmental policies. The course instructor will deliver the course content, assign deliverables, grade student outputs, hold weekly office hours, answer questions, and support students for success.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD candidates in Political Science or Environmental Studies or other related field in the social sciences. Preferences given to recent Ph.D. graduates and post-doctoral fellows with a completed dissertation on a topic related to climate change, climate justice, and/or climate policy.
qualifications_preferred: Prior teaching at the undergraduate level. Currently conducting research related to climate justice using an international and/or comparative lens.

job_title: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. 
The deadline to submit your application is September 26, 2022. For more information, you may contact: Angela Niazmand, Undergraduate and TA Administrator, Department of Statistical Sciences, University of Toronto
700 University Ave- Rm 9160- 6, Ontario Power Building, Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5, www.statistics.utoronto.ca, E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact
jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated. Duties will include any or all of the following: attending lectures, running 
tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on on-line discussion boards, participating in training 
sessions, meeting with the instructors, holding office hours, grading student homework including written reports, and 
assisting with grading of tests and exams.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior undergraduate students (third and fourth year) with strong background in statistics and exemplary communication skills may also be considered.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate student with strong background in statistics, as well as excellent communication and writing skills, and the ability to interact well with undergraduate students.
